The pink birthmark on the right side of the patient's face extending from the forehead to the zygomatic arch suggests Sturge-Weber syndrome, which is associated with prominent intraparenchymal white matter calcification. The other options do not fit with the presentation and medical history of the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pink birthmark on the right side of the patient’s face extending from the forehead to the zygomatic arch strongly suggests the diagnosis of Sturge-Weber syndrome. This syndrome is associated with prominent intraparenchymal white matter calcification, which would be the most likely finding on a head CT. The other options are less likely given the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presentation suggests Sturge-Weber syndrome, which is characterized by a port-wine birthmark and calcification of the brain's white matter. Therefore, the most likely finding on a head CT would be prominent white matter calcification. The other options are not characteristic of this syndrome.

A CT scan is the imaging of choice for diagnosis. None of the other options are characteristic of Sturge-Weber syndrome.

The birthmark on the right side of the patient's face may indicate the presence of Sturge-Weber syndrome, which is associated with prominent intraparenchymal white matter calcification. This is a common cause of pediatric seizures. A head CT should be ordered to confirm this suspicion. The other options are less likely causes in this case.

The presence of a pink birthmark on the right side of the face extending from the forehead to the zygomatic arch suggests the possibility of Sturge-Weber syndrome, which is associated with prominent intraparenchymal white matter calcification. We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s age and history of a first seizure suggest a possible underlying brain abnormality. The birthmark also suggests possible Sturge-Weber syndrome, which is associated with leptomeningeal angiomas that can cause intraparenchymal white matter calcification. A head CT scan can be used to confirm this finding. The other options are less likely based on the patient’s history and presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A pink birthmark on the face could indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome, which is associated with leptomeningeal angiomatosis and prominent intraparenchymal white matter calcification. CT or MRI is used to diagnose this syndrome. A non-enhancing hemispheric lesion or intraparenchymal hemorrhage would suggest other causes of seizure. A subependymal nodule is associated with tuberous sclerosis but not Sturge-Weber syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The pink birthmark on the patient's face suggests a diagnosis of Sturge-Weber syndrome, which is associated with prominent intraparenchymal white matter calcification on head CT. The other options are less likely in this clinical scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of seizure and a birthmark on the right side of her face, which suggests Sturge-Weber syndrome. This syndrome is associated with prominent intraparenchymal white matter calcification. A non-enhancing hemispheric lesion or subependymal nodule is possible but less likely, and intraparenchymal hemorrhage is unlikely since there is no history of trauma. A CT scan of the head is necessary to confirm the diagnosis.
